20101221180046.000|20101221180048.000|TR0|population was 308.7 million.  That's up 
20101221180048.000|20101221180051.000|TR0|9.7 percent over the past decade.  That, 
20101221180051.000|20101221180053.000|TR0|by the way, is the slowest growth rate 
20101221180053.000|20101221180056.000|TR0|since the Great Depression in the 1930s.

20101221181036.000|20101221181039.000|TR0|people sleeping on terminal floors.  Many 
20101221181039.000|20101221181041.000|TR0|since Saturday.  When they'll be able to

20101221181339.000|20101221181342.000|TR0|
20101221181342.000|20101221181344.000|TR0|(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
20101221181344.000|20101221181347.000|TR0|
20101221181347.000|20101221181349.000|TR0|VELSHI:  Live pictures of the White House 
20101221181349.000|20101221181352.000|TR0|in Washington, D.C. Looks kind of nice 
20101221181352.000|20101221181354.000|TR0|over there.  All right.  Let's talk about 
20101221181354.000|20101221181356.000|TR0|Web sites for a second.  Right now, every 
20101221181356.000|20101221181359.000|TR0|Website on the Internet is created equal 
20101221181359.000|20101221181401.000|TR0|so you're able to see everything and read 
20101221181401.000|20101221181404.000|TR0|everything at equal speeds.  Your Internet 
20101221181404.000|20101221181406.000|TR0|provider cannot limit what you view 
20101221181406.000|20101221181409.000|TR0|online, as long as it's legal, you get to 
20101221181409.000|20101221181411.000|TR0|view all Web sites the same way, that's 
20101221181411.000|20101221181414.000|TR0|called network neutrality.  And the FCC, 
20101221181414.000|20101221181416.000|TR0|the Federal Communications Commission, 
20101221181416.000|20101221181419.000|TR0|wants to keep it that way
20101221181419.000|20101221181421.000|TR0|
20101221181421.000|20101221181424.000|TR0|So, today, the FCC voted to approve net 
20101221181424.000|20101221181426.000|TR0|neutrality rules.  Don't change the 
20101221181426.000|20101221181429.000|TR0|channel.  This, actually, affects you.  
20101221181429.000|20101221181431.000|TR0|But first, let's break down what net 
20101221181431.000|20101221181434.000|TR0|neutral means.
20101221181434.000|20101221181436.000|TR0|
20101221181436.000|20101221181438.000|TR0|Here's how the Internet works.  Web sites 
20101221181438.000|20101221181441.000|TR0|like Facebook, Skype, Netflix, YouTube, 
20101221181441.000|20101221181443.000|TR0|Google, millions of others, well, these 
20101221181443.000|20101221181446.000|TR0|are called content providers.  OK?  That 
20101221181446.000|20101221181448.000|TR0|content is, then, funneled to an Internet 
20101221181448.000|20101221181451.000|TR0|service provider.  AT , Verizon, Comcast, 
20101221181451.000|20101221181453.000|TR0|Time Warner Cable and lots of others.  
20101221181453.000|20101221181456.000|TR0|Content providers, Internet service 
20101221181456.000|20101221181458.000|TR0|providers. Don't worry about the fact 
20101221181458.000|20101221181501.000|TR0|sometimes these two are mixed.  They're 
20101221181501.000|20101221181503.000|TR0|the same companies.  These service 
20101221181503.000|20101221181506.000|TR0|providers, then, push to Web sites out to 
20101221181506.000|20101221181508.000|TR0|your home or your computer or your 
20101221181508.000|20101221181511.000|TR0|wireless whatever it is.  With the 
20101221181511.000|20101221181513.000|TR0|Internet now surpassing television, when 
20101221181513.000|20101221181516.000|TR0|it comes to consumption of media, everyone 
20101221181516.000|20101221181518.000|TR0|in here is trying to make money.
20101221181518.000|20101221181520.000|TR0|
20101221181520.000|20101221181523.000|TR0|So, let's talk about how Internet 
20101221181523.000|20101221181525.000|TR0|companies make money.  Web sites mostly 
20101221181525.000|20101221181528.000|TR0|sell advertising.  They are selling 
20101221181528.000|20101221181530.000|TR0|someone else, an advertiser access to the 
20101221181530.000|20101221181533.000|TR0|fact you go to their website.  That's, 
20101221181533.000|20101221181535.000|TR0|generally, how it happens.  Some Web sites 
20101221181535.000|20101221181538.000|TR0|like Netflix, for instance, sell 
20101221181538.000|20101221181540.000|TR0|subscriptions.  You won't find advertising 
20101221181540.000|20101221181543.000|TR0|there.  They're paying for the service.  
20101221181543.000|20101221181545.000|TR0|Internet service providers sell access to 
20101221181545.000|20101221181548.000|TR0|those Web sites via broadband.  They 
20101221181548.000|20101221181550.000|TR0|provide the internet superhighway.  That's 
20101221181550.000|20101221181553.000|TR0|the road on which the Internet travels.  
20101221181553.000|20101221181555.000|TR0|But watching movies online, for instance, 
20101221181555.000|20101221181558.000|TR0|puts a bigger strain on networks than 
20101221181558.000|20101221181600.000|TR0|reading e-mails does.  And, now, some 
20101221181600.000|20101221181602.000|TR0|Internet service providers want to ration 
20101221181602.000|20101221181605.000|TR0|out the Internet access and split it into 
20101221181605.000|20101221181607.000|TR0|tiers.
20101221181607.000|20101221181610.000|TR0|
20101221181610.000|20101221181612.000|TR0|OK.  Here's the problem.  Some Internet 
20101221181612.000|20101221181615.000|TR0|service providers control Internet access 
20101221181615.000|20101221181617.000|TR0|also offer, let's say, video services of 
20101221181617.000|20101221181620.000|TR0|their own. Let's use Comcast as an 
20101221181620.000|20101221181622.000|TR0|example.  Imagine if Comcast was able to 
20101221181622.000|20101221181625.000|TR0|limit Netflix's use of the big Internet 
20101221181625.000|20101221181627.000|TR0|pipe.  It could block or significantly 
20101221181627.000|20101221181630.000|TR0|slow down Netflix so users, instead, would 
20101221181630.000|20101221181632.000|TR0|watch Comcast videos online.  This isn't 
20101221181632.000|20101221181635.000|TR0|to say it's happening today, but there are 
20101221181635.000|20101221181637.000|TR0|people in the - in the industry who are 
20101221181637.000|20101221181640.000|TR0|worried that it could happen in the 
20101221181640.000|20101221181642.000|TR0|future.  Some say it's not a concern.
20101221181642.000|20101221181644.000|TR0|
20101221181644.000|20101221181647.000|TR0|Let's compare it to a grocery store, for 
20101221181647.000|20101221181649.000|TR0|instance.  Let's say there's one grocery 
20101221181649.000|20101221181652.000|TR0|store in your town, and that grocery store 
20101221181652.000|20101221181654.000|TR0|sells bread.  All different kinds of 
20101221181654.000|20101221181657.000|TR0|bread.  All these different bread are 
20101221181657.000|20101221181659.000|TR0|different companies.  They're made by 
20101221181659.000|20101221181702.000|TR0|different bakeries.  All of a sudden, this 
20101221181702.000|20101221181704.000|TR0|grocery store tells the bread makers that 
20101221181704.000|20101221181707.000|TR0|they would only sell one type of bread in 
20101221181707.000|20101221181709.000|TR0|the store.  Their bread, actually.  The 
20101221181709.000|20101221181712.000|TR0|only bread you could buy would be the same 
20101221181712.000|20101221181714.000|TR0|brand.  Nobody else could get their bread 
20101221181714.000|20101221181717.000|TR0|into that store.  Does that sound fair?
20101221181717.000|20101221181719.000|TR0|
20101221181719.000|20101221181722.000|TR0|Well, the argument from some of the 
20101221181722.000|20101221181724.000|TR0|Internet service providers is that they're 
20101221181724.000|20101221181726.000|TR0|footing the bill for the equipment and the 
20101221181726.000|20101221181729.000|TR0|maintenance to bring the Internet into 
20101221181729.000|20101221181731.000|TR0|your home, so they need to ration and 
20101221181731.000|20101221181734.000|TR0|regulate the content running through their 
20101221181734.000|20101221181736.000|TR0|pipes - make money where they see the 
20101221181736.000|20101221181739.000|TR0|opportunity to do that.
20101221181739.000|20101221181741.000|TR0|
20101221181741.000|20101221181744.000|TR0|Let's talk about your home and this tiered 
20101221181744.000|20101221181746.000|TR0|system that some providers are suggesting. 
20101221181746.000|20101221181749.000|TR0| The Internet comes, basically, via a pipe 
20101221181749.000|20101221181751.000|TR0|like this.  And, right now, everything 
20101221181751.000|20101221181754.000|TR0|that goes into the Internet is equal.  
20101221181754.000|20101221181756.000|TR0|Right?  So, if I'm watching video online 
20101221181756.000|20101221181759.000|TR0|from my house, you know, I can - let's say 
20101221181759.000|20101221181801.000|TR0|I'm watching it on YouTube.  All right?  
20101221181801.000|20101221181803.000|TR0|It goes into the pipe. All right?
20101221181803.000|20101221181806.000|TR0|
20101221181806.000|20101221181808.000|TR0|Then I want to Skype with somebody. That 
20101221181808.000|20101221181811.000|TR0|goes into the tube. What about Facebook?  
20101221181811.000|20101221181813.000|TR0|Do that.  Netflix.  All of that goes 
20101221181813.000|20101221181816.000|TR0|through the tube at the same price.  And 
20101221181816.000|20101221181818.000|TR0|it all, as you can see, from the bottom, 
20101221181818.000|20101221181821.000|TR0|sometimes it's a little slow, but, 
20101221181821.000|20101221181823.000|TR0|generally speaking, it all comes out.
20101221181823.000|20101221181826.000|TR0|
20101221181826.000|20101221181828.000|TR0|Now, let's say you had a two-tiered 
20101221181828.000|20101221181831.000|TR0|system, where you charged some people for 
20101221181831.000|20101221181833.000|TR0|the ability to use the big pipe, but they 
20101221181833.000|20101221181836.000|TR0|want to divide up the pipe, and if you 
20101221181836.000|20101221181838.000|TR0|just want to surf the web and write e- 
20101221181838.000|20101221181841.000|TR0|mails, you need a smaller pipe.
20101221181841.000|20101221181843.000|TR0|
20101221181843.000|20101221181845.000|TR0|If I want to watch videos online, I'm 
20101221181845.000|20101221181848.000|TR0|going to need the larger pipe.  So some 
20101221181848.000|20101221181850.000|TR0|providers say I should pay more money for 
20101221181850.000|20101221181853.000|TR0|the access of the larger pipe, unless I'm 
20101221181853.000|20101221181855.000|TR0|only doing things that fit into the 
20101221181855.000|20101221181858.000|TR0|smaller pipe.  And increasingly there's 
20101221181858.000|20101221181900.000|TR0|less and less of that around, as you can 
20101221181900.000|20101221181903.000|TR0|see.
20101221181903.000|20101221181905.000|TR0|
20101221181905.000|20101221181908.000|TR0|Now, some people say this division is 
20101221181908.000|20101221181910.000|TR0|actually censorship. Others say doing this 
20101221181910.000|20101221181913.000|TR0|will kill innovation in the country.  Yet 
20101221181913.000|20101221181915.000|TR0|others say that you shouldn't regulate the 
20101221181915.000|20101221181918.000|TR0|Internet at all.  And this rule is a way

20101221182007.000|20101221182009.000|TR0|
20101221182009.000|20101221182012.000|TR0|DAVID GOLDMAN, STAFF WRITER, CNNMONEY.COM: 
20101221182012.000|20101221182014.000|TR0| No, it was a pretty good explanation, 
20101221182014.000|20101221182017.000|TR0|actually.  The main concern for net 
20101221182017.000|20101221182019.000|TR0|neutrality advocates is that there's going 
20101221182019.000|20101221182022.000|TR0|to be information that you're going to 
20101221182022.000|20101221182024.000|TR0|have to pay more for.  So, you know, for 
20101221182024.000|20101221182027.000|TR0|instance, a Comcast or a Time Warner Cable 
20101221182027.000|20101221182029.000|TR0|or one of these Internet service providers 
20101221182029.000|20101221182032.000|TR0|that you talked about might make you pay 
20101221182032.000|20101221182034.000|TR0|more to access amazon.com than eBay or 
20101221182034.000|20101221182037.000|TR0|maybe it's going to allow you better 
20101221182037.000|20101221182039.000|TR0|access to Amazon than eBay or even block 
20101221182039.000|20101221182042.000|TR0|one of those services.  So what the FCC 
20101221182042.000|20101221182044.000|TR0|did today was to put forth net neutrality 
20101221182044.000|20101221182047.000|TR0|regulations so that those kind of things 
20101221182047.000|20101221182049.000|TR0|can't happen.
20101221182049.000|20101221182051.000|TR0|
20101221182051.000|20101221182054.000|TR0|VELSHI:  David, we should be clear that 
20101221182054.000|20101221182056.000|TR0|this is not by any means the end game.  
20101221182056.000|20101221182059.000|TR0|This could go to Congress where there are 
20101221182059.000|20101221182101.000|TR0|some people who oppose it.  This could end 
20101221182101.000|20101221182104.000|TR0|up in the courts.  But let's just try and 
20101221182104.000|20101221182106.000|TR0|explain to our viewers what the analogies 
20101221182106.000|20101221182109.000|TR0|are.  And one that I came across from 
20101221182109.000|20101221182111.000|TR0|Barry Diller of Interactive Corporation, 
20101221182111.000|20101221182114.000|TR0|he said, if you don't have net neutrality, 
20101221182114.000|20101221182116.000|TR0|if you allow the Internet companies, the 
20101221182116.000|20101221182119.000|TR0|Internet service providers to do what some 
20101221182119.000|20101221182121.000|TR0|suggest they should be able to do, that 
20101221182121.000|20101221182124.000|TR0|would be like, what did he say, it would

20101221182513.000|20101221182516.000|TR0|Ali, 308 million people in this country 
20101221182516.000|20101221182518.000|TR0|and the growth rate in those 10 years, 9.7 
20101221182518.000|20101221182521.000|TR0|percent.  That sounds like a lot, and

20101221182526.000|20101221182528.000|TR0|it's the slowest growth rate here since 
20101221182528.000|20101221182531.000|TR0|the Great Depression.
20101221182531.000|20101221182533.000|TR0|
20101221182533.000|20101221182536.000|TR0|Why?  Well, the fertility rate is now 2.1. 
20101221182536.000|20101221182538.000|TR0| That means women in this country are

20101221182540.000|20101221182543.000|TR0|average.  And that's down from the 3.7 
20101221182543.000|20101221182545.000|TR0|that we saw in baby boom years.  But also

20101221184017.000|20101221184020.000|TR0|
20101221184020.000|20101221184022.000|TR0|On the screen we're showing you different 
20101221184022.000|20101221184025.000|TR0|time lapses of the move from across the 
20101221184025.000|20101221184027.000|TR0|country.  An eclipse happens when the 
20101221184027.000|20101221184030.000|TR0|Earth blocks the sun's light from hitting 
20101221184030.000|20101221184032.000|TR0|the moon.  So basically the Earth's shadow 
20101221184032.000|20101221184035.000|TR0|is now being cast on the moon, the moon 
20101221184035.000|20101221184037.000|TR0|can't reflect anything.  So that's the 
20101221184037.000|20101221184040.000|TR0|Earth's shadow you're seeing on the moon.
20101221184040.000|20101221184042.000|TR0|
20101221184042.000|20101221184045.000|TR0|The Winter Solstice marks the day when the 
20101221184045.000|20101221184047.000|TR0|Earth's tilt is farthest away from the 
20101221184047.000|20101221184050.000|TR0|sun, which also makes it the longest day 
20101221184050.000|20101221184052.000|TR0|of the year.  It was only viewable for 
20101221184052.000|20101221184054.000|TR0|watchers in North America, Greenland and 
20101221184054.000|20101221184057.000|TR0|Iceland.

20101221184318.000|20101221184320.000|TR0|people get out. If there are people who

20101221184454.000|20101221184457.000|TR0|
20101221184457.000|20101221184459.000|TR0|VELSHI:  OK.  So in this movie, the

20101221184506.000|20101221184509.000|TR0|

20101221184511.000|20101221184514.000|TR0|I," this is where we talk about it. Ideas, 
20101221184514.000|20101221184516.000|TR0|innovation.  Bullets made of sound waves 
20101221184516.000|20101221184519.000|TR0|that can be used by the military and in 
20101221184519.000|20101221184521.000|TR0|medicine.  Here to explain her design is 
20101221184521.000|20101221184524.000|TR0|Chiara Daraio.  She is an assistant 
20101221184524.000|20101221184526.000|TR0|professor of aeronautics and applied 
20101221184526.000|20101221184529.000|TR0|physics for the California Institute of 
20101221184529.000|20101221184531.000|TR0|Technology. Chiara, is that an 
20101221184531.000|20101221184534.000|TR0|exaggeration to say what is depicted in 
20101221184534.000|20101221184536.000|TR0|the movie is actually possible?
20101221184536.000|20101221184539.000|TR0|
20101221184539.000|20101221184541.000|TR0|CHIARA DARAIO, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR, 
20101221184541.000|20101221184543.000|TR0|CALIFORNIA INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY:  Hi, 
20101221184543.000|20101221184546.000|TR0|Ali.  Well, that's quite still away from 
20101221184546.000|20101221184548.000|TR0|where we are right now, but some bullets 
20101221184548.000|20101221184551.000|TR0|do exist.  And that's part of what we've 
20101221184551.000|20101221184553.000|TR0|been doing so far.
20101221184553.000|20101221184556.000|TR0|
20101221184556.000|20101221184558.000|TR0|VELSHI:  What is it?       DARAIO:  Right. 
20101221184558.000|20101221184601.000|TR0| So, what we define as a sound bullet is a 
20101221184601.000|20101221184603.000|TR0|compact burst of energy, a single pulse of 
20101221184603.000|20101221184606.000|TR0|acoustic energy or sound that can form in 
20101221184606.000|20101221184608.000|TR0|traveling a host material -- for example, 
20101221184608.000|20101221184611.000|TR0|air or water or a solid medium.  So, 
20101221184611.000|20101221184613.000|TR0|usually acoustic waves travel in trains of 
20101221184613.000|20101221184616.000|TR0|crests of high pressure and low pressure 
20101221184616.000|20101221184618.000|TR0|regions that follow each other.  Similar 
20101221184618.000|20101221184621.000|TR0|to what you see waves in an ocean or 
20101221184621.000|20101221184623.000|TR0|ripples in a pond.
20101221184623.000|20101221184625.000|TR0|
20101221184625.000|20101221184628.000|TR0|What we do is we create a bullet, which is 
20101221184628.000|20101221184630.000|TR0|consistent of only a single high pressure 
20101221184630.000|20101221184633.000|TR0|region that can achieve very, very large 
20101221184633.000|20101221184635.000|TR0|altitudes.
20101221184635.000|20101221184638.000|TR0|
20101221184638.000|20101221184640.000|TR0|VELSHI:  What can the military, for 
20101221184640.000|20101221184643.000|TR0|instance, do or what can people -- what 
20101221184643.000|20101221184645.000|TR0|can you do with the sound bullet?
20101221184645.000|20101221184648.000|TR0|
20101221184648.000|20101221184650.000|TR0|DARAIO:  Sound bullets can replace many of 
20101221184650.000|20101221184653.000|TR0|our - of today's technology in terms of 
20101221184653.000|20101221184655.000|TR0|acoustic waves.  Acoustic waves are not 
20101221184655.000|20101221184658.000|TR0|used just by the military.  For example, 
20101221184658.000|20101221184700.000|TR0|there are many biomedical applications 
20101221184700.000|20101221184703.000|TR0|like ultrasonic imaging or surgery, for 
20101221184703.000|20101221184705.000|TR0|example, to remove kidney stones or image 
20101221184705.000|20101221184707.000|TR0|babies in the belly of a mother.
20101221184707.000|20101221184710.000|TR0|
20101221184710.000|20101221184712.000|TR0|At the same time, you can use acoustic 
20101221184712.000|20101221184715.000|TR0|waves to test, for example, integrity of 
20101221184715.000|20101221184717.000|TR0|materials in structure like cracks in a 
20101221184717.000|20101221184720.000|TR0|pipeline or the integrity of an airplane 
20101221184720.000|20101221184722.000|TR0|wing.  Some bullets have much larger 
20101221184722.000|20101221184725.000|TR0|amplitude, which means they can improve 
20101221184725.000|20101221184727.000|TR0|the signal to noise ratio and they have a 
20101221184727.000|20101221184730.000|TR0|much more compactly support wave, which 
20101221184730.000|20101221184732.000|TR0|means they can achieve shorter pulses and 
20101221184732.000|20101221184735.000|TR0|better resolution than current 
20101221184735.000|20101221184737.000|TR0|technologies.
20101221184737.000|20101221184740.000|TR0|
20101221184740.000|20101221184742.000|TR0|This, together with being extremely 
20101221184742.000|20101221184744.000|TR0|controllable, would allow better ability, 
20101221184744.000|20101221184747.000|TR0|scanning ability of images that people 
20101221184747.000|20101221184749.000|TR0|desire to acquire, for example.
20101221184749.000|20101221184752.000|TR0|
20101221184752.000|20101221184754.000|TR0|VELSHI:  I want to show you a picture that 
20101221184754.000|20101221184757.000|TR0|we have here, a graphic we have which 
20101221184757.000|20101221184759.000|TR0|shows one of these sound bullets being 
20101221184759.000|20101221184802.000|TR0|used on someone's brain.  What are the 
20101221184802.000|20101221184804.000|TR0|medical applications of this?
20101221184804.000|20101221184807.000|TR0|
20101221184807.000|20101221184809.000|TR0|DARAIO:  So, that's a schematic diagram 
20101221184809.000|20101221184812.000|TR0|that represents one of the potential 
20101221184812.000|20101221184814.000|TR0|applications of our technology.  The idea 
20101221184814.000|20101221184817.000|TR0|of being able to focus sound in a very 
20101221184817.000|20101221184819.000|TR0|narrow spot and with a much higher 
20101221184819.000|20101221184822.000|TR0|precision, higher energy so that you can 
20101221184822.000|20101221184824.000|TR0|either, for example, in theory, image 
20101221184824.000|20101221184826.000|TR0|parts of the human body or focus energy so 
20101221184826.000|20101221184829.000|TR0|that you can increase the temperature in, 
20101221184829.000|20101221184831.000|TR0|for example, cause death of undesired 
20101221184831.000|20101221184834.000|TR0|cells.  For example, tumor cells.  This is 
20101221184834.000|20101221184836.000|TR0|a technique used in technology today and 
20101221184836.000|20101221184839.000|TR0|called ipotherma (ph).
20101221184839.000|20101221184841.000|TR0|
20101221184841.000|20101221184844.000|TR0|VELSHI:  All right. And finally, we're 
20101221184844.000|20101221184846.000|TR0|-you said we're some distance away from 
20101221184846.000|20101221184849.000|TR0|what I showed in that movie clip.  Where 
20101221184849.000|20101221184851.000|TR0|are we with this?  I mean, obviously, 
20101221184851.000|20101221184854.000|TR0|we're not looking to invent a gun. Where

20101221184856.000|20101221184859.000|TR0|ability to have sound go in a bullet as 
20101221184859.000|20101221184901.000|TR0|opposed to a wave?

20101221184904.000|20101221184906.000|TR0|DARAIO:  So, right now we are in the proof 
20101221184906.000|20101221184908.000|TR0|of principle stage. We in our laboratory

20101221184913.000|20101221184916.000|TR0|well as an experimental proof of principle 
20101221184916.000|20101221184918.000|TR0|for the creation of the sound bullets.  
20101221184918.000|20101221184921.000|TR0|Which means we've been able to test and 
20101221184921.000|20101221184923.000|TR0|demonstrate their feasibility and 
20101221184923.000|20101221184926.000|TR0|experimenting in the lab. It was done in

20101221184928.000|20101221184931.000|TR0|
20101221184931.000|20101221184933.000|TR0|We're now bringing the technology forward, 
20101221184933.000|20101221184936.000|TR0|trying to redesign a lens that's more 
20101221184936.000|20101221184938.000|TR0|automated, more controllable and 
20101221184938.000|20101221184941.000|TR0|scaleable.  And also that is capable of 
20101221184941.000|20101221184943.000|TR0|generating bullets that travel in water, 
20101221184943.000|20101221184946.000|TR0|for example, and fluids so that they're 
20101221184946.000|20101221184948.000|TR0|closer for applications. For example, for 
20101221184948.000|20101221184950.000|TR0|underwater detection of vehicles similar 
20101221184950.000|20101221184953.000|TR0|to Sonars or in the human body.

20101221185323.000|20101221185325.000|TR0|this.  They are Arizona, Florida, Georgia,

20101221185357.000|20101221185400.000|TR0|the country and governorships around the 
20101221185400.000|20101221185402.000|TR0|country.  So as they redraw those 
20101221185402.000|20101221185405.000|TR0|districts, that's going to be very good 
20101221185405.000|20101221185407.000|TR0|for the Republican party.
20101221185407.000|20101221185410.000|TR0|
20101221185410.000|20101221185412.000|TR0|But let me give you one big caveat here, 
20101221185412.000|20101221185415.000|TR0|which is very important to keep in mind.  
20101221185415.000|20101221185417.000|TR0|The states that are gaining congressional 
20101221185417.000|20101221185420.000|TR0|seats are states in which there are large 
20101221185420.000|20101221185422.000|TR0|minority populations, hence the gain. And 
20101221185422.000|20101221185425.000|TR0|those are populations -- Hispanic 
20101221185425.000|20101221185427.000|TR0|populations, for example -- which the 
20101221185427.000|20101221185430.000|TR0|Democratic party has lately gained a lot 
20101221185430.000|20101221185432.000|TR0|of traction with. So, this could help the 
20101221185432.000|20101221185435.000|TR0|Democrats in those states.  So, you know, 
20101221185435.000|20101221185437.000|TR0|it's a very, very complex situation.
20101221185437.000|20101221185439.000|TR0|
